Valued but not mission-critical. Useful for enhancing convenience and accessibility.

Okta Verify presents a usability barrier for students, impacting their overall experience.

Students find it useful as a reminder to complete onboarding tasks and keep themselves on track. 
Students find the onboarding checklist design intuitive. They appreciate being able to see task completion status and noted that the illustrative hints for clearing all tasks make it clear and easy to follow for commencing students. Having option to view completed tasks is also important to them.

Students expect the system to be accurate, up to date, and personalised — it should correctly recognise completed tasks and not block progress due to system errors or tasks that cannot be completed immediately.

Students expressed interest in having more items included in the checklist. Beyond onboarding, several students suggested turning the checklist into an ongoing feature that offers additional recommended actions.
Even when actions are directly linked, students still find link to the instructional content as second option will be helpful for better understanding and context.
Students see high value in the dashboard progress widget, especially since this information is currently hard to access elsewhere.
Students show strong interest in tracking their performance and receiving grade estimations within the portal.
Features that surface related academic information, such as assessments, grades/results, and next-step recommendations—are highly desirable and reduce cognitive load.
Students want census dates consolidated in the portal to avoid checking multiple sources.
Students want control over their dashboard layout and content visibility to tailor it to their needs.
While students are interested in a unified deadline feature, some prefer to continue using Canvas. To shift behaviour, our platform must offer clear added value beyond Canvas notifications.
The phrase “you may fail” is considered too blunt and potentially triggering. Students suggest reframing to something like “Here’s what you need to pass this subject.”
Students emphasise the importance of including wellbeing resources alongside academic support in the “at risk” experience.
Students appreciate being able to view all related information and statuses at a glance on the landing page.

Students highlighted the importance of having direct deep links to where actual transactions occur (e.g., study plan, timetable). They see tutorial content as a helpful secondary option, and will only be useful for the first time user.
Students appreciate having deadlines and calendar events listed on the same page, but express concerns about how far ahead the calendar view extends.
Students confirm the importance of personalised content, for example, having accurate deadlines that reflect spec-con outcomes and individual enrolment.
Students rely on personal calendars to plan their day. They want deadlines surfaced in the portal, but stress the importance of integration with third-party calendars.
Students are cautious of sharing their location data with the university.
Students want agency over how sensitive or potentially triggering information is displayed or hidden, for example, deadlines.
Locating rooms remains a major pain point. Existing navigation tools are insufficient, particularly for indoor or building-specific guidance.
Places of interest section aligns well with student needs. However, they request additional details such as availability, accessibility status, and direct links to booking systems.
Photos of buildings and directional arrows are helpful for students to remember and navigate campus locations.
Students are enthusiastic about using external navigation apps, but note that these do not currently solve the core issue of room-level wayfinding.
There is strong interest in a consolidated calendar.
Overall impact
Okta Verify presents a usability barrier for students, impacting their overall experience.

Some students express caution about seeing sensitive content such as WAM or progress on the dashboard or personal info on the portal. They want the ability to hide such information or prefer an added layer of protection.
Displaying personal details alongside direct links to update them is well received and considered helpful by students.
Students strongly affirm the usefulness of the My Records page as a centralised hub for finding academic and administrative documents.
Students suggest supporting multiple export methods, including emailing documents to themselves and batch downloading files.
While filter and search features are popular, students also want the ability to sort the document list for easier navigation and retrieval.
There is clear demand for the ability to apply document directly within the My Records page.
User Story (Optional): Order documents in a unified interface

Insight: Students use Personalised and Unique Features: Currently, the lack of distinct features affects students' willingness to use the portal, as many tasks can be completed elsewhere. In our research, 5 out of 13 participants expressed a need for personalised features in the student portal.

Respecting Existing Workflows: Many students have expressed that while they think that my.unimelb could be improved, they are satisfied with their current workflows. When asked what they would like to change, some students said that it would be better to limit change so that they wouldn't have to learn new things. This is correlated with the student being nearing their graduation, suggesting that some students are unwilling to learn new workflows if there is an existing workflow that works. Many students use different features in my.unimelb differently. This means that changes to core features in my.unimelb should be changed with all students' unique workflows with university administration in mind.
User Story (Optional): Allow users to decide when to switch to updated portal versions

Insight: Okta Verification is a painful experience: All of our participants highlighted the inconvenience caused by frequent Okta verification prompts. While most do not view it as a complete barrier to accessing my.unimelb, it significantly impacts the overall user experience. On average, participants agree that undergoing verification once per day is tolerable, acknowledging its importance for security reasons. This was a frequent major unprompted pain point.

The mobile view and interface of my.unimelb is inadequate: Most of our participants emphasized the importance of improving the mobile experience, as they are dissatisfied with its current state. They believe it is a significant barrier that prevents them from accessing my.unimelb and other related services on their mobile devices. This was a major pain point often brought up by participants.
Most students view my.unimelb as a link hub that connects all the platforms of Melbourne University into one central place.

Students have to figure out how to best utilise my.unimelb on
their first use of the platform
The ability for students to find their classrooms and buildings is a pain point that came up during the interview in several students.
